results.title: Noise destroys
results.creator_credit: Mike Woolveridge, Phillip Mark-Law, John Honey, Tasmanian Film Corporation and Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1979 film deals with the effects of industrial noise on hearing. Presented as a dramatic short film, the narrative follows the protagonist, Len, as he discovers he is partially deaf due to twenty years of working with loud machines in a factory and goes on a crusade to improve working conditions. The film is directed at employers as well as employees, showing the importance of wearing safety gear and machines being modified or insulated to limit sound production. The film contains light-hearted moments of comedy, as Len goes about convincing his colleagues and management of the significance of the issue.

Produced by the Tasmanian Film Corporation for the Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Cast: Max Cullen, Brian Duhig, Barry Pierce, John Hale, Keith Jarvis, Barrie Muir, Jack Perry, Richard Meredith, Billie Hammerberg, Tony Boden, Kevin Lacey, Don Glover, Tracy Lee, Bob Gunning, Peter Lewis, Matthew Rhodes

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Ned Kelly: paintings by Sidney Nolan
results.creator_credit: Alan Harkness, Tim Burstall, Patrick Ryan and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: The story of Australia’s best known bushranger is told through the paintings of Sidney Nolan, accompanied by a ballad played on the guitar. Made with the co-operation of the Museum of Modern Art of Australia.

results.title: Minh: a Vietnamese
results.creator_credit: Nick Torrens, Jan Sharp and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our multicultural society”.
A look at the life of a Vietnamese refugee in Australia. Minh talks about his life and hopes for his children in his new country.

results.title: A matter of survival: toxic solvents
results.creator_credit: R Hurley, J Sherman, S.T. Evans and CSIRO
results.brief_description:
In this 1963 film we see the dangers of working in contact with benzene vapours in a science laboratory. Most of the footage takes place in the CSIRO Chemical Research Laboratories, where the scientists enact scenes to show the safety precautions that should be observed, including avoiding breathing the vapours; avoiding spilling the liquid; replacing stoppers in bottles; washing hands; and always using the fume cupboard when pouring the liquid. The film includes an animated opening sequence, an ominous metronomic soundtrack to indicate levels of danger and footage of female scientists in the laboratory.

Produced by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO) Film Unit.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: The Man on the beat
results.creator_credit: Patricia Murray, Ralph Kemplen, Roger MacDougall and Merlin Films
results.brief_description: The duties and training of a London policeman, known over the world for his courtesy. The London policeman is unarmed, and his duties vary from finding lost children to directing traffic. Dealing with crime is only an occasional part of the ordinary London policeman’s job.

results.title: Launceston
results.creator_credit: W. H. Shepherd, John Edwards, Peter Young, Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life in Australia”.
Aspects of life in Launceston. Industries include Paton and Baldwins woollen mills, Repco ball bearing factory, timber mills and furniture manufacturers. Shows schools, the general hospital, churches, and the historic home of Entally built in 1820. Motor racing at Longford, bicycyle racing, water skiing and archery are popular forms of recreation. Theatres, restaurants and night clubs, provide a variety of evening entertainment.

results.title: Language at twelve (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Andrew Frazer, Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch Your Language”.
Intended primarily to emphasise the diversity and complexity of language in the life of a 12-year-old. This film focuses on two 12-year-olds who are involved in a school language project. Shows their interaction with a sufficient number of significant people in their lives for us to gain an impression of how the demands upon their speech shift. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Kangaroos. Part 2. Varieties
results.creator_credit: Ian Walker, John Shaw, David Bairstow and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Wildlife”.
Shows some of the variously adapted species of kangaroos in their natural environments: rat Kangaroos, quokkas, tree kangaroos, forest wallabies, rock wallabies and others.

results.title: Industrial Britain
results.creator_credit: John Grierson, Edgar H. Anstey, Robert Joseph Flaherty and Empire Marketing Board
results.brief_description: In 1931, with Nanook, Moana and Tabu behind him, Flaherty came to London to collaborate with John Grierson’s new government-supported documentary unit at the Empire Marketing Board. By 1932, Grierson had recruited a number of young men to the unit who he coached on film projects. This documentary resulted from the collaborative efforts and contributions of such a team. The film celebrates the craftmanship of British workers and as it captures the skills of potters, machinists, glassblowers and other tradesmen engaged in their work. Photographed by Robert Flaherty with additional photgraphy by Basil Wright, Arthur Elton and John Grierson. Edited by Edgar Anstey and John Grierson. Narrated by Donald Calthrop.

results.title: In the Wake of the Stars
results.creator_credit: Walter Batty, Mark McDonald, Bede Whiteman and Cinesound
results.brief_description: Aviation came quickly in Australia. In the early days reliable DC3’s carried everyone and everything. Then new faster and more comfortable aircraft were sought: the Fokker Friendship from Holland, the super Viscount from France and turbo jets from America. During training flights the attractions of gracious Amsterdam, gay Paris, England’s spring, New York’s people, Rome’s buildings and Australia’s scenic attractions are presented.
